review.title: To study the phenomenon of the Moravec's Paradox
review.abstract: "Encoded in the large, highly evolved sensory and motor portions of the human brain is a billion years of experience about the nature of the world and how to survive in it. The deliberate process we call reasoning is, I believe, the thinnest veneer of human thought, effective only because it is supported by this much older and much powerful, though usually unconscious, sensor motor knowledge. We are all prodigious Olympians in perceptual and motor areas, so good that we make the difficult look easy. Abstract thought, though, is a new trick, perhaps less than 100 thousand years old. We have not yet mastered it. It is not all that intrinsically difficult; it just seems so when we do it."- Hans Moravec Moravec's paradox is involved with the fact that it is the seemingly easier day to day problems that are harder to implement in a machine, than the seemingly complicated logic based problems of today. The results prove that most artificially intelligent machines are as adept if not more than us at under-taking long calculations or even play chess, but their logic brings them nowhere when it comes to carrying out everyday tasks like walking, facial gesture recognition or speech recognition.

We are all wonderful Olympians in the realms of perception and motor skills, so good that we make the difficult seem easy. However, abstract thinking is a new trick that may be less than 100,000 years old. We have not mastered it yet. It is not so difficult in itself; it only seems so when we do." -Hans Moravec's paradox is related to the fact that it is the seemingly simpler everyday problems that are harder to implement in a machine than the seemingly complicated logical problems of today.

sections.heading: Results
sections.text: A few minutes of conversation with each of these artificial intelligence chatbots clearly shows the lack of depth in the conversation. They lack: 1.Interpretative skills 2.Any form of memory - Each instruction is a new statement for them, regardless of the input they received before handover.3.Cognitive skills However, most of the bots were able: 1.Answers to simple / complex math problems 2.Perform their predefined goal.

sections.heading: Discussion/Conclusion
sections.text: The above conversations clearly indicate that it is not so difficult to implement a few skills in machines such as calculation and to respond with specific answers when receiving specific input. However, when it comes to abstractions from the usual instruction of bots / machines, it becomes difficult to give any form of reasonable results. Hence, we conclude that it is the conscientious measures that are more difficult to implement in artificial intelligence than those that logic.Citations / Referenceshttp: / en.wikipedia.org / wiki / Rodney _ Brookshttp: / en.wikipedia.org / wiki / Marvin _ Minskyhttp: / en.wikipedia.org / wikikiprokikia.org /
